Hey everyone!
I have a superbill question. 
If I am paid with an FSA or HSA card - should I provide a superbill for them to put it towards their deductible?

comments.text: No correlation between HSA payments and deductible. If you aren't in network they aren't getting any credit towards their deductible. And it sounds like you aren't.

post_text: If your mobile business is registered in NJ, but you have a PT license in PA and NJ, are you able to treat people in PA under the business? How does that work?

post_text: Hello guys! What are your tax strategies to lower your taxes for mobile therapist and having an LLC? Thank you in advance!

comments.text: Best thing is keeping track of mileage!

Hey! A few things that help, track all your work expenses (mileage, gear, CEUs, software, etc.), look into the home office deduction if you do admin at home, and consider a Solo 401(k) or SEP IRA to lower taxable income. If you're making good money, switching your LLC to an S-Corp can also save on taxes. Def worth talking to a tax pro who gets the mobile therapy world!

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello guys! What are your tax strategies to lower your taxes for mobile therapist and having an LLC? Thank you in advance!

post_text: Iâ€™m in CA- anyone have resources for hiring a PT and all the legal paperwork/considerations? Please only CA businesses reply, our state is VERY different from other states. Thank you!!!

comments.text: You will need to register for a CA EDD employer account for payroll taxes, apply for a Workers Compensation policy (mine is through State Fund), and an accounting program to process payroll (I use Quickbooks). Your employee should fill out a W4 form that you will need for payroll and income taxes.

We use Gusto which manages payroll but also handles a lot of the hiring paperwork for us and submits everything to the state and federal that it needs to. In California, they absolutely have to be an employee, not a contractor. Thatâ€™s the main thing about our state. That and the requirements for sick pay thatâ€™s like 40 hours of paid leave per year now.

post_text:
Any feedback from those who have made the leap to B&M?

Iâ€™m at a place in my business (6 years as a mobile therapist) where I need to change it up. As I weigh the pros/cons with the transition to a B&M model one that stands out is the loss of work/life balance. I believe the long term outcome can be positive financially as well as impact on the community but at what cost? Iâ€™m currently experiencing paralysis by analysis ðŸ˜‚ but need to make some big decisions soon!

comments.text: Itâ€™s really nice to have all the things in one place and not have to pack up and carry it to each house.  The overhead becomes a factor but you still run the show.  You can decide to see the same number of ppl with less profit or in a smaller window then try to rent it out later in the day or weekends to make up cost.  I liked the recommendation to hire a mobile provider then take b&m clients.

I started as mobile and opened a clinic 2 years ago. I am risk averse so I am subleasing from a prosthetic clinic so we can collab on his limb loss patients and I can see other patients there as well. Luckily rent is low and I haven't bought a ton of expensive equipment because the caseload hasn't grown as I hoped. BUT... every time I put the key in the door and see my business name on the wall, I am so happy so I'm going to keep it and work on growing that side of my business

post_text:
I have a question regarding payroll. I started my cash pay LLC in April of this year with an LLC bank account for business expenses/income. I have yet to pay myself out as I'm somewhat lost on what the heck I'm doing.  I was going to save 30% of my income for tax expenses then transfer the rest to my personal bank account.  Would this be an ok thing to do? Or would you advise using a payroll software? If so, what kind do you like? 

I really appreciate everyone's input.

comments.text: I started my cash business 3 years ago and had the same questions.  My best advice is to find a good CPA and ask a lot of questions.  I recently got a new CPA whose goal is to decreased my tax bill as much as possible.  There are laws that differ in each state so a good CPA in your state will understand how to maximize your take home and avoid some pitfalls.

Hire a bookkeeper or accountant to calculate your taxes quarterly.  They'll tell you what percentage to save before paying yourself and show you where to send your local and federal checks to each quarter.  They can also file your business tax return for the year during tax season.

There are laws that differ in each state so a good CPA in your state will understand how to maximize your take home and avoid some pitfalls.

post_text:
Tax Prep!
Is it ok to do your own taxes?  Is Turbo Tax good enough for a small LLC?  Tell me the pros and cons.  I know itâ€™s last minute.  I was about to upload all my info to a CPA but then I figured I might as well do it myself.  I am the only employee with basically a side hustle income.  Thanks for your input!

comments.text:
Just a quick back story. I'm from a farm and have helped my parents with tax prep for many years but they always went to a CPA to put it all together. I thought I knew everything.

This year, I decided to do it on my own. Last year was the first year of my PT business. I also had a W-2 and another small business. I just received the biggest return of my life... I mean huge. All because I used TurboTax, learned the system, and studied the rules on the IRS website. 

Teach a man to fish as they say. Some CPAs are amazing. However, most of them just collect your info and submit. They don't have time to go through all the potential write offs and holes. My GF was about to submit hers last week. I calculated it and she initially owed $750. After I was done, she received a $1600 refund. I learned all of that info from doing mine this year.
We just paid $900 to have ours done. We have 2 very small LLCs (just us). I think I might return to Turbo Tax!

post_text:
Hi all! Anyone have recommendations for financial advisors or resources willing to advise on student loans?

Before opening my biz I was at a non-profit and 4 years into a PSLF plan (it was the major mental hurdle to jumping ship and doing my own thing). Between that and COVID, Iâ€™ve been on this IDR plan making minimal payments for a while.

Now Iâ€™m 3+ years into business and Iâ€™ve tripled my previous salary but havenâ€™t quite figured out the approach to the loans. Still technically on an IDR plan and paying the minimum which would theoretically be forgiven in 12 years.

I usually pay my debt aggresively (or dont carry it)but also understand basic math and see that Iâ€™d pay FAR less over the life of the loan if I were to keep paying the minimum another 12 years vs aggressively paying down over 200K in debt with $ I could invest into scaling my biz.

Our financial advisor doesnâ€™t understand the world of loans and doesnâ€™t trust the government to forgive so he has been minimally helpful and the loan servicers/government are useless on this.    

If anyone can speak to this or has a recommended resource please let me know or DM me!

comments.text: If your non profit service was specifically to get your loans forgiven that is reasonable. But otherwise, you took out loans, you should pay them back. If you have an IDF plan and you 3x your income, you need to recalculate that payment anyway. This a more personal matter but if you take out loans, you should be the one to pay them back, not the tax payer. Obviously I don't know all you situation but you did ask facebook so here's my 2c. Congrats on going out on a limb and succeeding with your business!

Following. Had a few planners look at my debt vs income and % of return if I were to invest in the market. Given the % rates of my loans and volatility of the market, even playing it safe, the advisors ultimately concluded it maybe a wash and best advised to pay off as quick as possible, versus carrying debt.  But am all ears for others input.

post_text: Anyone in here work with strongman athletes frequently? Have a client with bilateral shoulder pain who I am evaluating this week. Previous labral repair and torn labrum in the other shoulder. My background is more heavily into powerlifting but assuming given the amount of overhead pressing (also what heâ€™s having pain with) Iâ€™m gonna want to work on a lot of stabilization. And a lot will depend on what I find on Eval but any other big things I might not be thinking of for this population? TIA!

comments.text: Youâ€™re probably already really well versed in all of this but on assessment Iâ€™d pay attention to T/S and lat mobility as well as shoulder IR mobility, strength, and endurance especially behind the back. Also throwing some things at them that they may not do frequently in training like bench dips, Turkish get ups, bamboo bar work along of your planned pressing may be helpful, too!

As mentioned above, overhead pressing is normally an issue, but also consider not simply overhead pressing but power production in the overhead position. 

And often in less than â€œbiomechanically optimalâ€ positions. 

So looking at thoracic mobility and control in those positions.

post_text: I have a full time job plus my own llc that I see pts from Luna and  other home care agency. I have separate bank account for  my llc. My question is regarding tax how to save money and claim expenses. Do I take salary from it to reduce tax or it does not matter. Total income from llc will be around 16-17k. TIA

comments.text: This has many answers depending on personal overall financial situation.  You should be listing expenses following the IRS schedule C. You should meet with accountant to identify your actual tax liability but start with reserving 30% of profit until you get that input. Quarterly estimated tax filings should be done. When earning less than $50_70k profit in a year most accountants do not recommend you being an employee and electing to file as a S corporation. Again an overall financial situation question
Look into the book Profit First.

post_text:
Hi all! Question about paying yourself:
I have an S-corp in CA, it is cash based PT only and my side business on top of my full time HH job. 
I have finally hit $10k profit this year and would like to pay myself. Apart from paying California taxes such as the annual franchise tax, what is the best way to organize paying yourself? Do I use a payroll service as an employee with a W2? Also, how do I calculate income tax on the amount paid to myself?

I tried to use the search for this but couldn't come up with any useful results. Any input would be appreciated as I'm new to this! Thank you :)

comments.text: I believe you have to pay yourself a "reasonable" salary for your work. That's what my accountant told me. I'd highly suggest asking an accountant and using one consistently that can help you with this. I've been surprised more than once with the rules I didn't realize existed. I'm in Ohio, so rules may differ, but the differences between LLC and s Corp consist of payroll, including payroll services, paying both sides of taxes, different tax forms, 401k matching etc.

post_text: Has anyone decided to go with an HSA tied to a mutual fund with catastrophic care coverage vs. standard insurance for themselves and their employees?  Thinking pros vs. cons on something like this.  To be honest Iâ€™ve heard this could be a fiscally smart long term option but I donâ€™t even know where to begin.

comments.text: Have maxed out contributions to a HSA for years. Significant tax advantages (pre-tax contributions, tax free withdrawal, tax free capital gains -- all assuming these fund qualified medical expenses). I also leave it fully invested in S&P500 Index Funds (as opposed to higher cost mutual funds) and covered put options on S&P500 ETFs. It's about as hands off as it gets for passive management while avoiding ridiculous fees. One could argue (myself included) that a ROTH IRA should be fully funded prior to an HSA. Important to remember that if one can afford to pay for medical expenses currently out of pocket that you can "reimburse" yourself at any point down the road!

Max out both roth and hsa if possible. Tax advantages are huge for later in life. If you are nervous about a catastrophic medical bill, you can always keep the equivalent of your deductible in the hsa non-invested. The math in most scenarios usually favors the hsa plan vs a quality plan IF you contribute to the hsa account.

full_thread_text:

Thinking pros vs. cons on something like this.  To be honest Iâ€™ve heard this could be a fiscally smart long term option but I donâ€™t even know where to begin.

COMMENT 1: Have maxed out contributions to a HSA for years. Significant tax advantages (pre-tax contributions, tax free withdrawal, tax free capital gains -- all assuming these fund qualified medical expenses). I also leave it fully invested in S&P500 Index Funds (as opposed to higher cost mutual funds) and covered put options on S&P500 ETFs. It's about as hands off as it gets for passive management while avoiding ridiculous fees. One could argue (myself included) that a ROTH IRA should be fully funded prior to an HSA. Important to remember that if one can afford to pay for medical expenses currently out of pocket that you can "reimburse" yourself at any point down the road!

COMMENT 2: Max out both roth and hsa if possible. Tax advantages are huge for later in life. The math in most scenarios usually favors the hsa plan vs a quality plan IF you contribute to the hsa account.

post_text: For those who are solo practicioners do you find itâ€™s worth it financially to work on your own from a tax standpoint? Iâ€™ve heard the amount of tax you pay is significantly higher than if youâ€™re an employee.

comments.text:
You pay a self employment tax that covers Medicare (2.9%) and SS (12.4%).

Yes, owning my time is worth much more to me. We homeschool, I have a mobile PT practice, I participate in pro bono events, I run a mentoring/coaching service, and I'm able to run my business ebdeavors the way I desire. All-around win for me and it hasn't been a financial hit tax wise either.

Being taxed as an Scorp helps significantly! Make sure you work with an accountant that is an Enrolled Agent (EA)â€” they are experts in the tax department for small businesses. My accountant has saved me tons of money by knowing the ins and outs of all the nuisances of being self employed

I have a patient with Medicare (I'm a participating provider) and UHC AARP supplemental plan, I called to verify benefits... Medicare deductible not met and AARP doesn't cover the deductible, they pay 20% once deductible is met. What do I charge the patient until the deductible is met... The full allowed amount of the visit? 20% of the allowed amount?
When submitting claims, do I then put on the CMS1500 form how much the patient paid? When will Medicare know when the deductible is met?

Thanks for any input, this is my first time seeing a patient where the deductible isn't met!

comments.text: Colleen Tickner Crawford did you figure out what to do? Iâ€™m in the same boat right now? If you were collecting the payment up front, what did you do to show that you did that so that can apply towards their deductible? You still bill Medicare?

Option 1: treat but know that what you Re supposed to be reimbursed will go towards the deductible and not you. That is about 2 visits. 

Option 2: have the patient pay the $226 to you and then treat.

Option 3: if they are not willing to pay deductible let them know that therapy services will begin once deductible is met.

post_text:
Tax Question:

If I am a 1099 employee but also have a small scale practice on the side, is my income from my 1099 job part of my personal business income as well.

Example: I made about 5k in each this year, 10k total. I spent about 7k on expenses and supplies for personal business.
Do I pay taxes on the 5k income from the 1099 job and mark a 2k loss in personal business, or would they be lumped together and I pay taxes on the 3k profit total?

Will also run this by my accountant for confirmation, but any insight is appreciated.

comments.text: If you are a single member LLC or sole proprietor it all lumps into your personal anyway. Keep it all separate for acct but tax wise it's all together, the accts do the magic.
I was told that all untaxed income in related fields gets lumped together    But I keep it separate and present it  so my accountant can see.  They make the educated decision on losses and taxes.

full_thread_text:
POST: Tax Question:

If I am a 1099 employee but also have a small scale practice on the side, is my income from my 1099 job part of my personal business income as well.

Do I pay taxes on the 5k income from the 1099 job and mark a 2k loss in personal business, or would they be lumped together and I pay taxes on the 3k profit total?

Will also run this by my accountant for confirmation, but any insight is appreciated.

COMMENT 1: If you are a single member LLC or sole proprietor it all lumps into your personal anyway. Keep it all separate for acct but tax wise it's all together, the accts do the magic.

COMMENT 2: I was told that all untaxed income in related fields gets lumped together    But I keep it separate and present it  so my accountant can see.  They make the educated decision on losses and taxes.

post_text: Wondering what the correct way of doing this is since Iâ€™ve heard some mixed infoâ€¦when you track miles for tax deduction do you only track from your house to the clients or round trip? Thanks, have learned a lot from this group!

comments.text: You track your mileage from patient to patient house. Youâ€™re not reimbursed from your house to your first patients house and from your last patients house to your home. Like you donâ€™t get reimbursed to commute to/from work.

Your CPA will be able to help clarify. Jenni Lyn and Samantha Rothman are both right. 
Additionally, you are able to write off EITHER your miles OR a portion of your gas - but not both.  Again, your CPA can tell you which is most beneficial FOR YOU.
